Problem:
Consider the heat equation \\( u_t = k \\Delta u \\) in a domain \\( D \\) with boundary conditions prescribed on \\( \\partial D \\). An input function \\( h(x,t) \\) represents the external heat added per unit time. We consider the impact of the integral transformation \\( T[u](x,t) = u(x,t) + \\int_0^t h(x, \\tau) \\, d\\tau \\) on the system over time t.

If \\( T[u] \\) is applied to the initial condition \\( u_0 \\) at t = 0, then allowed to evolve according to \\( u_t = k \\Delta u \\) without further intervention, will the temperature distribution \\( u(x, t) \\) at time T be solely determined by \\( u_0 \\), independent of \\( h(x,t) \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( T[u] \\) adds the effect of the input function \\( h(x,t) \\) to the initial condition, which modifies the initial state of the heat distribution. As a result, the temperature distribution at any later time T depends not only on \\( u_0 \\) but also significantly on the cumulative effect of \\( h(x,t) \\) over time.
